title: A file created in C:\Users\<user>\AppData\Local\lxss\root from Windows isn't visible in WSL
body: I would like to be able to create files in the WSL root directory using Windows tools (VSC, NotePad++...)

comments.body: What on Earth? I was so excited to use WSL because I could finally use Notepad++ to edit my Linux files. Disappointed..
Just a slap in the faces of everyone that this is marked as won't fix...

What about a Windows global hook that detects writes to files under lxss, saves them to the VirtualStore (or maybe %TEMP% since VS is deprecated), and then runs bash with the proper mv command after converting the filepath to posix format? Not sure if the File System Redirector can be used for this. My solution at the moment is to run programs inside a very permissive sandbox (just to virtualize writes to lxss) and then use rsync to copy the files to their final location.
Ok, so this is in the backlog since 20th December 2016. It's December 2017 now. Any progress?

Shame I would be on par with my mac colleagues who can easily navigate between local DB/Python servers running on unix bash vs development & git running from UI under mac... :-(
Mac is gaining ground on development thanks to than... and I still have to have my dual boot... :-(

This feel like a basic functionality....Am sure there must be a huge challenge in the background.
Personally this is one of the first features I expected when I installed bash on Windows 10.
Unbelievable this is still not fixed...
How is this not supported? Its literally the reason why I use windows instead of linux, because of the GUI, where I can manipulate files on a code editor and run via linux binaries

Tools like 'mat' or 'exiftool' are useless if WSL cannot read files saved in Windows file system.
So Bash become useless :(

Hi, is there any updates on copying files from windows to Bash Path?
Thanks
Why is this not supported? WSL is a developer solution and I'd like to use Visual Code to manage my code files, including creating new ones. You can't expect developers to code in vim all the time?

Really, the linux home should at *LEAST* be mounted in conjunction with the user's home in windows, and share files/editing, etc.  If nothing else, this could be a samba mount inside lsw, or for that matter a fuse fs mount... Or however /mnt/c/... works.   TBH my main desire is linux tools via bash, and a gui editor in windows...  Not being able to edit my profile directory from the gui is irksome to say the least.
Editing a file in Windows makes the file invisible to Linux too.

According to a GitHub comment, this is because Windows apps are unaware of WSL-specific metadata.
https://github.com/Microsoft/BashOnWindows/issues/87#issuecomment-214567251
Manipulating the Linux filesystem from Windows is currently unsupported and can cause corruption, see https://github.com/Microsoft/BashOnWindows/issues/45
Eddy: Have you tried turning off "Hide protected operating system files"? (it's in the same place as show hidden files, folders and drives).

Ok, this is bizarre. This is the second reference to that path that I've seen today. I messed up my .bashrc in VIM and now BASH crashes on launch. I do not have that file path on any of the machines that I installed BASH on ....
